title-group.article-title: Study of open crack in rotor shaft using changes in frequency response function phase

abstract.p: In recent years, significant efforts have been devoted to developing non-destructive techniques for damage identification in structures. This study investigated the effects of cracks and damages on the integrity of structures, with a view to detect, quantify, and determine their extents and locations. Previous works have used parameters, such as, changes in natural frequencies and mode shapes, as detectors. However, such parameters are not sensitive enough to detect early defects. In this paper, phase measurements are sought. Measurements of the acceleration frequency responses at different points on each rotor shaft were taken using a multi-channel frequency analyzer. The damage detection schemes used in this study depended on the changes in the phase of the measured acceleration frequency response functions. To study the changes of phases, it was interpreted in phase spectrum and Nyquist plot. Nyquist plot was used as it includes both real and imaginary parts of the amplitude and this was used to study phase shifts due to the presence of crack. The changes in phase depended on crack depth and how close the crack is to that mode shape node. Meanwhile, the changes in phase of lower eigenvectors were observed clearly. Thus, first mode shape was helpful in identifying the location of the crack. The vibration behavior of the rotor shaft was shown to be very sensitive to the crack depth, crack location and mode number. It is concluded that changes in phase as a function of crack depths and locations can be effective in crack detection methodology.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Crack detection is an important problem associated with high speed rotating machinery. A crack not detected in time could result in catastrophic failure and cause injuries and severe damage to machinery. The downtime cost due to the failure of rotating machinery could be high. On the other hand, if a crack is detected in its early stages, corrective action could be taken promptly or plans could be made in advance to replace the cracked part of the machinery.

There are several ways to deal with the structural integrity evaluation. There is a consensus that it is necessary to establish inspection procedures which systematically evaluate the structural integrity. The main techniques can be fundamentally broken down to non-destructive and destructive testing. Detection techniques based on non-destructive testing (NDT) has been preferred due to low cost and operational aspects related to the use of the analyzed structure. There are several non-destructive testing techniques available for crack detection, for example: visual examination, radiographic tests, ultrasonic testing, liquid penetrate tests and magnetic particle tests. However, all the above methods could not be utilized under operating conditions of the structures. Due to this limitation, it is now perceived that the monitoring of the global dynamics of structures offers promising alternatives for damage detection. There are methods for damage detection based on sensitivity and statistical parameters. Some methods are based on dynamic characteristics of structures such as natural frequencies, dynamic mode shapes, and structural damping. These methods have taken advantage of the present day development of modal analysis techniques with accurate measurements of modal parameters. When damage event occurs, the structural dynamic characteristics changes and this may be used as an indicator of damage.

There are a number of publications dealing with the problem of detection, localization and sizing of cracks. Based on the change in natural frequencies and mode shapes, several researchers attempted the detection of cracks in the structures with varying degree of success. Doebling et al. (1998) and Salawu (1997) gave reviews of research work on crack detection methods based on changes in modal parameters. Swamidas et al. (2003) presented damage detection schemes which depended on the measured changes in the first three natural frequencies and the corresponding amplitudes of the measured acceleration frequency response functions (FRFs). Lee and Chung (1999) also presented a non-destructive evaluation procedure for identifying a crack, the location and size of the crack, in a one-dimensional beam-type structure using the natural frequency data. Sayyad et al. (2012) used the measured axial natural frequencies to detect crack location and crack size in various beam structures.

In rotating shaft, a method has been developed to detect the existence and location of a crack in rotating shafts. The crack detection method is based on obtaining the Fourier transform of the response of the shaft. The amplitudes at the peaks of the Fourier transform of the response are used in a “residue” vector to identify and locate the crack (Ratan et al., 1996).

Mode shape data is another parameter used in crack detection study as examplified by several researchers (Ismail, 2012; Ismail and Ong, 2012; Ismail et al., 2011; in press). Ratcliffe (1997) presented a technique for locating damage in a beam that uses a finite difference approximation of a Laplacian operator on mode shape data. An alternative method is to use mode shapes in obtaining spatial information on sources of vibration changes. This is performed by using the mode shape derivatives, such as curvature (Ismail et al., 2006; Razak and Ismail, 2006). It is noted that for beams, plates, and shells, there is a direct relationship between curvature and bending strain. Absolute changes in mode shape curvature could be a good indicator of damage for the cantilever and simply supported analytical beam structures that they considered (Pandey et al., 1991). The changes in the curvature increase with increase in severity of damage. The curvature values were computed from the displacement mode shape using the central difference approximation. Fundamental mode shape was more sensitive to damage than the fundamental vibration frequency and it further confirms the sensitivity of the mode-shape method.

Stubbs and Osegueda (1990), Gomes and Silva (2008), Narayana and Jebaraj (1999), Kim and Stubbs (2003), and Ong et al. (in press) had utilized the sensitivity approach in their studies. In the sensitivity approach, damage in a structural element was estimated from a direct inverse solution of a change in the element stiffness if modal sensitivity was computed from an analytical model of the structure and changes in natural frequencies were measured from the structure. Even though the sensitivity approach could produce an estimation of location and severity of damage at the same time, reliable output might not be expected unless both the analytical model that should be accurate enough to compute the modal sensitivity and a large number of frequencies that should be accurately measured were provided.

The modal assurance criteria (MAC) was used by Fox (1992) to determine the level of correlation between modes from the test of an undamaged body flap and the modes from the test of the flap after it had been exposed to loading. The mode shapes were partitioned using various schemes, and the change in MAC across the different partitioning techniques was used to locate the structural damage. It was shown that shape changes such as the MAC are relatively insensitive to damage in a beam with a saw cut. The Coordinate Modal Assurance Criterion (COMAC) uses the numerical and experimental vibration modes to determinate the magnitude and position of the damage was shown by Iturrioz et al. (1999).

In later development, genetic algorithms became another alternative to identify the damage in structures. Ostachowicz et al. (1996) performed a series of tests with genetic algorithms used as a maximization tool to detect delamination sites on a cantilever composite beam. Sazonov et al. (2002) used the genetic algorithm to produce a sufficiently optimized amplitude characteristic filter to extract damage information from the strain energy mode shapes. Gomes and Silva (2008) used a genetic algorithm and a modal sensitivity method to identify and evaluate damage cases in a parametric numerical finite element model. A real coded genetic algorithm was used as an optimization tool. The results for the identification and evaluation of the damage in both methods were similar and comparable. Hassiotis (2000) presented an optimization algorithm which was formulated for the identification of damage in structures, when such damage was manifested by localized reductions in the stiffness of structural elements. The relationship between the stiffness of the structure and its natural frequencies had been presented as a set of underdetermined equations to be solved for the stiffness changes due to damage. Kanwar et al. (2007) used an artificial neural network (ANN) model to develop correlation between the damage in the frame of the reinforced concrete building with its known dynamic characteristics.

There are other detection schemes which involve finite elements that have been used to study and detect cracks (Nahvi and Jabbari, 2005). Benfratello et al. (2007) presented both numerical and experimental investigations in order to assess the capability of the non-Gaussianity measures to detect crack presence and position. Monte Carlo method is applied to evaluate in time domain the higher order statistics of a cantilever beam modeled by finite elements. Xiang et al. (2007) modeled the rotor system using finite element method of B-spline Wavelet on the Interval (FEM BSWI), while the crack was considered through local stiffness change. Based on Rayleigh beam theory, the influences of rotatory inertia on the flexural vibrations of the rotor system were examined to construct BSWI Rayleigh beam element. The new method could be applied to prognosis and quantitative diagnosis of crack in a rotor system.

Natural frequencies, mode shape, phase, and FRF amplitudes were usually the parameters being used to study open cracks. Although extensive work has been done in using FRF phase measurements to identify defects, however, most of the works are on civil engineering structures which are basically a static structure. This allows modal testing to be performed with considerable level of acceptance as the coherence is generally good. But when conducted on a shaft while in operation, the level of unaccounted forces is quite significant that model testing would produce very bad coherence. This is mainly due to the spectral averaging used in obtaining the FRF. The technique proposed by the author is based on Impact-synchronous Time Averaging originally developed by Rahman et al. (2011a). When averaging the data blocks of the artificially introduced impact forcing trace and its response trace is performed in the time domain prior to FRF operation, such process would eliminate all components of responses due to unaccounted forces not synchronized in frequencies and phases with the impact. Subsequent performance of FRF will produce a very good coherence with sufficient number of averages (Rahman et al., 2011b). Phase change is highly sensitive in the region around the natural frequencies. Therefore, using phase change would give a better chance of revealing any small defect as compared to other parameters.

Bentley Nevada has worked extensively on crack detection of shafts, but they are not based on FRF measurement. Instead phase change is measured of the 1x the running speed of the shaft triggered by the proximity probe.

The damage detection scheme presented in this paper utilized the experimental modal data, FRF phase. This study used the changes in the phase of the measured acceleration FRFs to examine the effect of a crack in shaft. To study the changes of phases, it was interpreted in Phase spectrum and Nyquist plot. Nyquist plot was used as it includes both real and imaginary part of the amplitude and this could be used to study phase shifts due to presence of crack.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: When excitation is applied, the equation of motion leads to the frequency response of the system. The frequency response is a complex quantity and contains both real and imaginary parts. It can be presented in polar coordinates as magnitude and phase as well.

Figure 1 shows the relationship between input, q and output, x. The relationship is governed by the given equation (1)x=H(ω)qeiωt where q is excitation force in force per unit mass and ω is the excitation frequency in rad/s. Figure 1.
Input–output relationship.
From general equation of motion, the FRF, H(ω), is defined as (2)H(ω)=1ωo 2-ω2+2σωi where ωo is undamped natural frequency in rad/s, σ is decay rate in rad/s.
Equation (2) can be rewritten as (3)H(ω)=ωo 2-ω2-2σωi(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2

The complex FRF consists of both real and imaginary components. In other words, it has magnitude and phase. H(ω) is a characteristic of the system. It will be a different function if its kind of input/output quantity has changed. It is worthwhile to mention here that once the system has been defined, the behavior of the input function does not affect H(ω).
Substituting equation (3) into equation (1) (4)x=ωo 2-ω2-2σωi(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2q(cosωt+isinωt)
Taking real component and it is given as (5)x=(ωo 2-ω2)cosωt+(2σω)sinωt(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2q
Rearranged equation (5) gives (6)x=(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2qcos(ωt-φ)
Therefore, equation (4) can be expressed in terms of magnitude and phase as (7)x=1(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2qcos(ωt-φ)

One method of presenting the data is to plot the polar coordinates, magnitude and phase versus frequency. At resonance, the magnitude is at maximum and is limited only by the amount of damping in the system. The phase ranges from 0° to 180° and the response lags the input by 90° at resonance.
In polar coordinates, magnitude of H(ω) is derived as (8)H(ω)=1(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2
And the phase angle φ is (9)φ=tan-1 (2σωωo 2-ω2 )

Another method of presenting the data is to plot the rectangular/Cartesian coordinates, the real part and the imaginary part versus frequency. For a proportionally damped system, the imaginary part is at maximum at resonance and the real part is zero.
In Cartesian coordinates as in equation (3), real part of H(ω) is derived as (10)H(ω)=ωo 2-ω2(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2 imaginary part of H(ω) is derived as (11)H(ω)=-2σω(ωo 2-ω2)2+(2σω)2

A third method of presenting the frequency response is to plot the real part versus the imaginary part. This is often called a Nyquist plot or a vector response plot. This display emphasizes the area of frequency response at resonance and traces out a circle.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
In this research, Bentley Nevada RK4 Rotor Kit as shown in Figure 2 was used. The rotor kit was 10 mm in diameter and 600 mm in length. It could closely simulate the actual rotating machine behavior. Its unique geometry and its ability for users to isolate and control individual machine characteristics made it useful as both a teaching tool and as a laboratory tool for theoretical research. Figure 2.
Bentley Nevada Rotor Kit (RK4).

Rotor shafts were prepared for open crack study and identification purposes. The shaft was first divided into eight measurement points, i.e. PT3 to PT10. The crack was cut in different sizes and location of the elements. Crack was simulated using computer numerical control (CNC) machine with the width of 0.2 mm as shown in Figure 3. Besides, Figure 4 shows a shaft with the depth of 4 mm and width of 1 mm was simulated with a normal saw to investigate the severity of serious damaged shaft. Figure 3.
Shafts with crack simulated by computer numerical control (CNC) machines with different sizes and location with the width of 0.2 mm.
Figure 4.
Shaft with crack simulated by saw with size of 4 mm × 1 mm.

These cracked shafts together with a healthy shaft were used to study and identify the open crack based on the change of natural frequencies, magnitudes, and phases. Total of nine cases which include one healthy shaft and eight shafts with single crack were simulated and investigated in the crack identification study. Case 0 is for healthy shaft. For cases 1, 2, 3, and 5, a single crack with the depth of 2 mm was created at PT4, PT5, PT7, and PT6, respectively, to simulate the crack at different locations. In addition, to study the effect of crack size, a single crack was induced using CNC machine at PT6 with the size of 1 mm, 2 mm, 3 mm, and 4 mm accordingly in cases 4, 5, 6, and 7. Case 8 is for crack at PT6, which was simulated by saw with the size of 4 mm × 1 mm.

The work was based on the experimental investigations of the effects of cracks and damages on the integrity of rotor, with a view to detect, quantify, and determine their extents and locations. Modal testing was performed using the self-developed modal testing application program in virtual instrument software, DASYLab on healthy shafts and shafts with different crack sizes and locations. Based on experimental modal testing results, the changes of phases between healthy shafts and shafts with a crack were studied in order to detect the presence of the crack and determine its location and size in the rotor shaft. The modal data that was obtained from the modal testing application programme was further processed in DASYLab for open crack study. Changes of magnitude and phase of FRF were plotted in the format of phase plot and Nyquist plot. Nyquist plot is based on the real and imaginary part of the amplitude. The phase shift due to the crack could be identified clearly from this plot. They were used for analysis and comparison between the healthy and damaged shafts.

The damage detection schemes used in this study depended on the measured changes in FRF phase of the first and second corresponding modes. From both phase spectrum and Nyquist plot, changes in phase between healthy and shafts with a crack can be easily visualized and studied. Changes of phases as a function of crack depths and locations were used to identify crack in the rotor.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
Comparison between the phase of healthy and damaged shafts was displayed and studied in phase spectrum. Phase is more sensitive to crack compared to amplitude. There is a phase shift when crack is simulated on the shaft. This change depends on how close the crack location is to the mode shape nodes, the phase shift of a mode is larger as the crack is near to the antinodal point of the corresponding mode shape. As shown in Figure 5, phase shift of shaft with crack at PT6 is the largest as it is located at the antinode of the first mode shape. The shift is followed by crack at PT5 and PT7 accordingly. Meanwhile, a crack at PT4 causes the smallest shift of phase as it is located far from the antinodal point of the first corresponding mode. Thus, it shows the similar trend as in natural frequency and amplitude where the crack at the antinodal point exhibits more significant change as tabulated in Table 1. Figure 5.

Amplitudes change is not good enough to study the crack at different locations for the higher modes. However, phase spectrum is sufficient for the study of a crack at various locations. As displayed in Figure 6, shift of phase is observed clearly for shafts with a crack when it is compared with a healthy shaft. PT4 is the antinodal point for this second mode. Therefore, the phase of the crack at PT4 shifts the most. Subsequent to that are cracks at PT5 and PT7, respectively. A crack at PT6 has the smallest phase shift as it is near to the nodal point in this second mode. As tabulated in Table 2, it is noticed that natural frequency change also shows the similar trend with phase change. However, the change is small as compared with the phase shift. Figure 6.

For shafts with different crack sizes, the phase shift of the damage rotor is monotonically increasing with the increment of the crack depth compared to healthy shaft. The results are displayed in Figures 7 and 8 where shafts with different crack sizes at PT6 are tested and the phase shift of first and second modes are studied. From these 2 figures, in both first and second modes, the shaft with the largest crack size which is 4 mm exhibits the most significant change in phase. The phase change becomes less significant for shafts with crack size of 3 mm, 2 mm, and 1 mm. It followed the similar trend as in natural frequency where larger crack size causes that particular shaft with crack to be more sensitive and induces greater change as in Tables 3 and 4. Finally, it is noticed that shift of phase is adequate and suitable to study open crack not only for different crack locations but also for different crack sizes. Figure 7.

Besides phase spectrum, Nyquist plot is another useful tool for open crack study. It includes phase in the analysis as the FRF data in magnitude and phase are processed into real and imaginary part of the amplitude. Figure 9 displays the Nyquist plot of first mode shape by comparing healthy shaft and shafts with cracks at various locations. From this Nyquist plot, it is observed that the amplitude in real and imaginary part of shaft with a crack located at PT6 is the most significant due to its proximity to the antinodal point of the first mode. The size of the Nyquist plot for a crack at PT5, PT7, and PT4 consequently becomes smaller for shafts with cracks located far from the antinode of the corresponding mode shapes. Figure 9.
Nyquist plot of first mode shape for different crack locations.

However, for the second mode, the Nyquist plot did not show the trend of second mode shape where crack at PT4 is estimated to exhibit the largest size of Nyquist plot. This is because the second mode is not sensitive enough to show the changes when it is displayed in Nyquist plot as the amplitude is included in the analysis. It is worthwhile to mention that when dealing with crack at different locations, only Nyquist plot of first mode should be used for the study and analysis.

When shafts with a crack of different sizes are displayed in Nyquist plot as shown in Figures 10 and 11, a similar trend is observed as in phase spectrum of both the first mode and the second mode. The shaft with the largest crack size, 4 mm, shows the largest radius in Nyquist plot. Nyquist plot for shafts with crack size of 3 mm, 2 mm, and 1 mm, respectively, become smaller while for a healthy shaft, the Nyquist plot is the smallest in radius. Thus, the first and second modes could be displayed in Nyquist plot as a tool to study the effect of various crack sizes on rotor shafts. Figure 10.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The detection of the presence of a crack in rotor shafts based on phase of FRF in experimental modal analysis results has been successful. The vibration behavior of the rotor shafts is shown to be very sensitive to the crack location, crack depth, and mode number. Ability to conduct tests while the machine is running and the high sensitivity of the detection method are features that can help an earlier detection of the onset of imminent damage.

An open crack could be studied based on the different analyses on the modal testing results obtained. The summary is as tabulated in Table 5. It is noticed that the first mode could be utilized for open crack study. The change of natural frequencies, amplitudes, and phases of the first mode between healthy and shafts with a crack could be used to study the effect of crack locations and sizes on shafts. Table 5.

Both the first and second modes could be utilized and the data could be analyzed in phase and natural frequency. The results could also be interpreted in Nyquist plot for better visualization and identification of the changes when the cracks were introduced on the shafts.

A higher mode like the second mode was not found to be useful in the location of cracks. However, changes of the phases of the second mode were significant to be used to differentiate the effect of crack location on the shaft. Although natural frequency is a more common parameter being used in the study of cracks, the phase change showed the most prominent results among the other modal parameters for open cracks study. It is worthwhile to mention here that phase is a better parameter than natural frequency to study crack of different locations and sizes. A single crack on the shaft can induce greater change in phase than change in natural frequency as shown in the results. Finally, changes in the parameter like phase, which is a function of crack location and crack size, could be used in crack detection methodology.
